form.longName: PhenX PX520501 - Motives Alcohol Tobacco And Other Substances General
form.preferredDefinition: The coping and enhancement subscales from the Drinking Motives Questionnaire Revised (DMQ-R) consist of 10 questions about the respondent's coping and enhancement motives (reasons) for drinking alcohol. The respondent is asked to respond to each question via a five-item scale ranging from 1 for "almost never/never" to 5 for "almost always/always."

headerInstruction.text: Below is a list of reasons people give for drinking alcohol (smoking cigarettes or using [insert name of drug of interest]). Thinking of all the times you drink (smoke cigarettes or use [insert name of drug of interest]), how often would you s..TRUNCATED

module.longName: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - General
module.preferredDefinition: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - General

question.questionText: 1. To forget your worries (to_forget_your_worries)
2. Because it helps you when you feel depressed or nervous (helps_when_depressed_or_nervous)
3. To cheer up when you are in a bad mood (to_cheer_up)
4. Because you like the feeling (you_like_the_feeling)
5. Because it's exciting (because_its_exciting)
6. To get high (to_get_high)
7. Because it gives you a pleasant feeling (gives_you_a_pleasant_feeling)
8. Because you feel more selfconfident or sure of yourself (more_selfconfident)
9. To forget about your problems (forget_about_your_problems)
10. Because it's fun (because_its_fun)

Scoring Procedure and Interpretation: The items were renumbered 110 from their original item numbers in the full Drinking Motives Questionnaire Revised (DMQR), but the order of the items is consistent. DMQR subscale/Scoring procedure: Coping Motives/Mean of items 1, 2, 3, 8, and 9 Enhancement Motives/Mean of items 4, 5, 6, 7, and 10 The scoring scheme reflects factors identified in the original publication. Factor structure may differ in individual studies. (scoring_20501)

protocol.longName: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - General
protocol.preferredDefinition: The coping and enhancement subscales from the Drinking Motives Questionnaire Revised (DMQ-R) consist of 10 questions about the respondent's coping and enhancement motives (reasons) for drinking alcohol. The respondent is asked to respond to each question via a five-item scale ranging from 1 for "almost never/never" to 5 for "almost always/always."

form.longName: PhenX PX520502 - Motives Alcohol Tobacco And Other Subsspecificalcoh
form.preferredDefinition: The Drinking Motives Questionnaire Revised (DMQ-R) consists of 20 questions about the respondent's reasons for drinking alcohol, falling into one of four categories for social, coping, enhancement, and conformity motives. The respondent is asked to respond to each question via a five-item scale ranging from 1 for "almost never/never" to 5 for "almost always/always."

headerInstruction.text: Here is a list of reasons people give for drinking alcohol. Thinking of all the times you drink, how often would you say that you drink for each of the following reasons? There are no right or wrong answers to these questions. If you no longer..TRUNCATED

module.longName: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Specific - Alcohol
module.preferredDefinition: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Specific - Alcohol

question.questionText: 1. To forget your worries (drink_to_forget_your_worries)
2. Because your friends pressure you to drink (friends_pressure_you_to_drink)
3. Because it helps you enjoy a party (drink_helps_enjoy_party)
4. Because it helps you when you feel depressed or nervous (drink_helps_when_depressed)
5. To be sociable (drink_to_be_sociable)
6. To cheer up when you are in a bad mood (drink_to_cheer_up)
7. Because you like the feeling (drink_because_like_the_feeling)
8. So that others won't kid you about not drinking (drink_so_others_wont_kid)
9. Because it's exciting (drink_because_its_exciting)
10. To get high (drink_to_get_high)
11. Because it makes social gatherings more fun (drink_makes_gatherings_more_fun)
12. To fit in with a group you like (drink_to_fit_in)
13. Because it gives you a pleasant feeling (drink_gives_pleasant_feeling)
14. Because it improves parties and celebrations (drink_improves_parties)
15. Because you feel more selfconfident or sure of yourself (drink_more_selfconfident)
16. To celebrate a special occasion with friends (drink_celebrate_special_occasion)
17. To forget about your problems (drink_to_forget)
18. Because it's fun (drink_because_its_fun)
19. To be liked (drink_to_be_liked)
20. So you won't feel left out (drink_wont_feel_left_out)

Scoring Procedure and Interpretation: DMQR subscale and scoring procedure: Social Motives= Mean of items 3, 5, 11, 14, and 16 Coping Motives= Mean of items 1, 4, 6, 15, and 17 Enhancement Motives= Mean of items 7, 9, 10, 13, and 18 Conformity Motives= Means of items 2, 8, 12, 19, and 20 Total Score: Sum of means for the four subscales. (scoring_420502)

protocol.longName: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Specific - Alcohol
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Drinking Motives Questionnaire Revised (DMQ-R) consists of 20 questions about the respondent's reasons for drinking alcohol, falling into one of four categories for social, coping, enhancement, and conformity motives. The respondent is asked to respond to each question via a five-item scale ranging from 1 for "almost never/never" to 5 for "almost always/always."

form.longName: PhenX PX520504 - Motives Alcohol Tobacco And Othersubstspecifictobac
form.preferredDefinition: The Brief Wisconsin Inventory of Smoking Dependence Motives (Brief WISDM) consists of 37 questions spanning 11 subscales about the respondent's reasons for cigarette smoking. Each question is answered on a seven-point scale ranging from 1 for "Not true of me at all" to 7 for "Extremely true of me." The Brief WISDM was developed from the full 68-item WISDM.

headerInstruction.text: Below are a series of statements about cigarette smoking. Please rate your level of agreement for each using the following scale. There are no right or wrong answers.

module.longName: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Specific - Tobacco
module.preferredDefinition: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Specific - Tobacco

question.questionText: 1. I often smoke without thinking about it (smoke_without_thinking)

validValue.meaningText: Not true of me at all
validValue.description: Not true of me at all

question.questionText: 2. Cigarettes control me (cigarettes_control_me)

validValue.meaningText: Not true of me at all
validValue.description: Not true of me at all

question.questionText: Scoring Procedure and Interpretation: Brief WISDM subscale and Scoring procedure:. Affiliative Attachment= Mean of items 11, 22, 26 Automaticity= Mean of items 1, 10, 14, 25 Loss of Control= Mean of items 2, 16, 21, 35 Cognitive Enhancement= Mean of items 6, 13, 32 Craving= Mean of items 4, 17, 23, 29 Cue Exposure/Associative Processes= Mean of items 8, 12, 24 Social/Environmental Goads= Mean of items 18, 27, 30 Taste= Mean of items 5, 15, 20 Tolerance= Mean of items 3, 28, 31, 36Weight Control= Mean of items 7, 19, 34 Affective Enhancement= Mean of items 9, 33, 37Total Score= Sum of means for the 11 subscales. The scoring scheme reflects factors identified in the original publications. Factor structure may differ in individual studies. (scoring_520504)

protocol.longName: Motives - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Specific - Tobacco
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Brief Wisconsin Inventory of Smoking Dependence Motives (Brief WISDM) consists of 37 questions spanning 11 subscales about the respondent's reasons for cigarette smoking. Each question is answered on a seven-point scale ranging from 1 for "Not true of me at all" to 7 for "Extremely true of me." The Brief WISDM was developed from the full 68-item WISDM.

form.longName: PhenX PX520405 - Expectancies Alcohol Tobacco And Other Substances Prescription Stimulant Drugs
form.preferredDefinition: The Prescription Stimulant Expectancy Questionnaire (PSEQ) is a 40-item instrument containing statements about the positive and negative effect expectancies of prescription stimulants, such as methylphenidate (Ritalin®, Concerta®), dextroamphetamine (Dexedrine®), and amphetamine and dextroamphetamine (Adderall®). It is scored on a 3-point Likert scale that ranging from 0 for "Not at all" to 2 for "Very often or always." The PSEQ has been used with recreational and medical users.

headerInstruction.text: The following pages contain statements about the effects of prescription stimulants, including Adderall®, Ritalin®, Concerta®, and Dexedrine®.

module.longName: Expectancies - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Prescription Stimulant Drugs
module.preferredDefinition: Expectancies - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Prescription Stimulant Drugs

question.questionText: Have you ever used a prescription stimulant (like Adderall® or Ritalin®) for any reason? (used_prescription_stimulant)

Read each statement carefully and respond according to your own personal thoughts, feelings, and beliefs about prescription stimulants now. We are interested in what you think about prescription stimulants, regardless of what other people might think. Whether or not you have had actual experiences with prescription stimulants yourself, you are to answer in terms of your beliefs about prescription stimulants. It is important that you respond to every question. There are no right or wrong answers. Please fill out the following questions according to your beliefs about the stimulant drug you know best. PLEASE BE HONEST. REMEMBER, YOUR ANSWERS ARE CONFIDENTIAL. RESPOND TO THESE ITEMS ACCORDING TO WHAT YOU PERSONALLY BELIEVE TO BE TRUE ABOUT A MODERATE AMOUNT OF STIMULANTS HOWEVER YOU DEFINE MODERATE (instructions_520405)
1. Distractions disappear. (distractions_disappear_stimulants)
2. I absorb new material the first time through. (absorb_material_first_time_stimulants)
3. I can't focus on more than one thing at a time. (cant_focus_stimulants)
4. I can focus very well. (focus_very_wel_stimulants)
5. I can ignore distractions more easily. (ignore_distractions_stimulants)
6. I can pay attention really well. (pay_attention_stimulants)
7. I can study for hours and hours. (study_for_hours_stimulants)
8. I can't hold still. (cant_hold_still_stimulants)
9. I can't sleep even if I want to. (cant_sleep_stimulants)
10. I can't calm down. (cant_calm_down_stimulants)
11. I don't end up daydreaming. (dont_daydream_stimulants)
12. I don't want to study without it. (dont_want_study_without_stimulants)
13. I enjoy studying a lot more. (enjoy_studying_more_stimulants)
14. I feel drained the next day. (feel_drained_next_day_stimulants)
15. I feel guilty for taking it. (feel_guilty_taking_stimulants)
16. I feel like I can't get through the day without it. (cant_get_throughday_without_stimulants)
17. I feel like I'm cutting corners to do well. (cutting_corners_stimulants)
18. I feel sick to my stomach. (sick_to_stomach_stimulants)
19. I feel twitchy. (feel_twitchy_stimulants)
20. I focus on unimportant tasks. (focus_unimportant_tasks_stimulants)
21. I get annoyed with myself for taking it. (annoyed_with_myself_for_stimulants)
22. I get nervous and edgy. (get_nervous_edgy_stimulants)
23. I learn very efficiently. (learn_efficiently_stimulants)
24. I need fewer breaks when I study. (need_fewer_study_breaks_stimulants)
25. I wish I could do as well without it. (wish_do_well_without_stimulants)
26. I worry that I'm addicted to it. (worry_im_addicted_stimulants)
27. I'm all amped up. (all_amped_up_stimulants)
28. It's no trouble to sit still. (no_trouble_sit_still_stimulants)
29. I've come to see it as a crutch. (crutch_stimulants)
30. My ability to focus is better. (ability_focus_is_better_stimulants)
31. My concentration is excellent. (concentration_excellent_stimulants)
32. My focus is crystal clear. (focus_crystal_clear_stimulants)
33. My head hurts. (my_head_hurts_stimulants)
34. My memory is better. (my_memory_is_better_stimulants)
35. My mind doesn't wander. (mind_doesnt_wander_stimulants)
36. My mind is razor sharp. (mind_razor_sharp_stimulants)
37. My thoughts follow more logically. (thoughts_follow_more_logically_stimulants)
38. My thoughts stay on track better. (thoughts_on_track_better_stimulants)
39. My work seems more interesting. (work_more_interesting_stimulants)
40. My heart races. (my_heart_races_stimulants)

Scoring Procedure and Interpretation :The Prescription Stimulant Expectancy Questionnaire (PSEQ) score is calculated by averaging the item scores. Half of the items (1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 11, 13, 23, 24, 28, 30, 31, 32, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38, and 39) are scored with 0 = "Not at all," 1= "Sometimes," and 2 = "Very often or always." The other half of the items (3, 8, 9, 10, 12, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 25, 26, 27, 29, 33, and 40) are reversescored with 2 = "Not at all," 1 = "Sometimes," and 0 = "Very often or always.". (scoring_520405)

protocol.longName: Expectancies - Alcohol, Tobacco, and Other Substances - Prescription Stimulant Drugs
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Prescription Stimulant Expectancy Questionnaire (PSEQ) is a 40-item instrument containing statements about the positive and negative effect expectancies of prescription stimulants, such as methylphenidate (Ritalin®, Concerta®), dextroamphetamine (Dexedrine®), and amphetamine and dextroamphetamine (Adderall®). It is scored on a 3-point Likert scale that ranging from 0 for "Not at all" to 2 for "Very often or always." The PSEQ has been used with recreational and medical users.
